Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_panic_std:
```c
_MHD_NORETURN static void
mhd_panic_std (void *cls,
               const char *file,
               unsigned int line,
               const char *reason)
{
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  fprintf (stderr,
           _ ("Fatal error in GNU libmicrohttpd %s:%u: %s\n"),
           file,
           line,
           reason);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) file;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) line;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) reason; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif
  abort ();
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code constructs in the snippet are standard C or ordinary macros and do not on their face represent compiler language extensions: the (void) casts are a standard idiom to suppress unused-parameter warnings; fprintf and abort are standard C library functions; the use of the _() macro is typically a regular macro/function (e.g. gettext) and is not a compiler language extension; preprocessor conditional (#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES / #else / #endif) is standard preprocessor usage; the function parameter and type declarations (void *, const char *, unsigned int) are standard C. Therefore no other fragments need investigation for Rule 1.2.
